title: Contributing to wqtrends
text: Small typos grammatical errors documentation may edited directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. YES: edit roxygen comment .R file R/. : edit .Rd file man/.

title: Contributing to wqtrends
text: make substantial pull request, always file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s problem. ’ve found bug, create associated issue illustrate bug minimal reprex.

title: Contributing to wqtrends
text: recommend create Git branch pull request (PR). Look Travis AppVeyor build status making changes. README contain badges continuous integration services used package. New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat. Contributions test cases included easier accept. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md current development version header describing changes made followed GitHub username, links relevant issue(s)/PR(s).

title: Contributing to wqtrends
text: Please note wqtrends project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Contributing to wqtrends
text: details.

title: Issues reporting guide
text: Please briefly describe problem output expect. question, please don’t use form. Instead, ask https://stackoverflow.com/ https://community.rstudio.com/. Please include minimal reproducible example (AKA reprex). ’ve never heard reprex , start reading https://www.tidyverse.org/help/#reprex. Brief description problem
code: # insert reprex here

title: Introduction to wqtrends
text: sample dataset rawdat included package used examples . dataset includes monthly time series data ~30 years nine stations South Bay, San Francisco Estuary. Data available 4 water quality parameters. data long format one observation per row. data pre-processed work GAM fitting functions included package. columns include date, station number, parameter name, value date. Additional date columns included describe day year (doy), date decimal time (cont_year), year (yr), month (mo character label). required model fitting use analysis/plotting functions. One GAM model can fit time series data. GAM fits additive smoothing functions describe variation response variable (value) time, time measured continuous number. basic GAM used package follows: S: value ~ s(year, k = large) cont_year vector measured continuous numeric variable annual effect (e.g., January 1st, 2000 2000.0, July 1st, 2000 2000.5, etc.). function s() models cont_year smoothed, non-linear variable. optimal amount smoothing cont_year determined cross-validation implemented mgcv package (Wood 2017) upper theoretical upper limit number knots k large enough allow sufficient flexibility smoothing term. upper limit k chosen 12 times number years input data. insufficient data available fit model specified k, number knots decreased data can modelled, e.g., 11 times number years, 10 times number years, etc. anlz_gam() function used fit model. First, raw data filtered select station 34 chlorophyll parameter. model fit using log-10 transformation response variable. Available transformation options log-10 (log10) identity (ident). log-10 transformation used default specified user. remaining functions use model results assess fit, calculate seasonal metrics trends, plot results. fit can assessed using anlz_smooth() anlz_fit(), former assesses individual smoother functions latter assesses overall fit. anlz_smooth() results show results fit cont_year smoother effective degrees freedom (edf), reference degrees freedom (Ref.df), test statistic (F), statistical significance (p-value). significance part based difference edf Ref.df. anlz_fit() results show overall summary model Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), generalized cross-validation score (GCV), R2 values. Lower values AIC GCV higher values R2 indicate better model fit. plotting functions show results different formats. appropriate response variable, model predictions back-transformed scales plot shown log10-scale preserve values results. show_prddoy() function shows estimated results day year separate lines year.  show_prdseries() function shows predictions model across entire time series. Points observed data lines predicted.  show_prdseason() function similar except model predictions grouped month. provides simple visual depiction changes month time. trend analysis functions can used statistically test seasonal changes.  Finally, show_prd3d() function shows three-dimensional fit estimated trends across year day year z-axis showing estimates response variable.
code: head(rawdat) #>         date station param     value doy cont_year   yr  mo #> 1 1990-02-27      18   chl 1.0333333  58  1990.156 1990 Feb #> 2 1990-04-18      18   chl 1.6333333 108  1990.293 1990 Apr #> 3 1990-05-30      18   chl 1.6000000 150  1990.408 1990 May #> 4 1990-07-30      18   chl 5.2333333 211  1990.575 1990 Jul #> 5 1990-12-06      18   chl 0.9333333 340  1990.929 1990 Dec #> 6 1991-02-06      18   chl 1.6333333  37  1991.099 1991 Feb tomod <- rawdat %>%  filter(station %in% 34) %>%  filter(param %in% "chl") mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = "log10") mod #>  #> Family: gaussian  #> Link function: identity  #>  #> Formula: #> value ~ s(cont_year, k = 348) #>  #> Estimated degrees of freedom: #> 219  total = 219.93  #>  #> GCV score: 0.07280572 anlz_smooth(mod) #>       smoother      edf   Ref.df        F p.value #> 1 s(cont_year) 218.9304 262.4482 4.788546       0 anlz_fit(mod) #>              AIC        GCV        R2 #> GCV.Cp -3.166885 0.07280572 0.6842621 ylab <- "Chlorophyll-a" show_prddoy(mod, ylab = ylab) show_prdseries(mod, ylab = ylab) show_prdseason(mod, ylab = ylab) show_prd3d(mod, ylab = ylab)

title: Introduction to wqtrends
text: Statistical tests evaluating trends available package. methods considered “secondary” analyses use results fitted GAM evaluate trends changes time. particular, significance changes time evaluated using mixed-effect meta-analysis (Sera et al. 2019) applied GAM results allow full propagation uncertainty methods. test includes plotting method view results.

title: Introduction to wqtrends
text: anlz_perchg() show_perchg() functions can used compare annual averages two time periods interest. functions require base test year inputs used comparison. one year can entered base test years, e.g., baseyr = c(1990, 1992, 1993) vs. testyr = c(2014, 2015, 2016). plot results one GAM, use show_perchg() function. plot title summarizes results.
code: anlz_perchg(mod, baseyr = 2006, testyr = 2017) #> # A tibble: 1 × 4 #>   baseval testval perchg     pval #>     <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1    9.78    5.35  -45.3 0.000376 show_perchg(mod, baseyr = 2006, testyr = 2017, ylab = "Chlorophyll-a (ug/L)")

title: Introduction to wqtrends
text: anlz_metseason(), anlz_mixmeta(), show_metseason() functions evaluate seasonal metrics (e.g., mean, max, etc.) years, including assessment trend selected years using mixed-effects meta-analysis modelling. functions require inputs seasonal ranges evaluate (doyend, doystr) years assessing trend seasonal averages/metrics (yrstr, yrend). anlz_metseason() function estimates seasonal metrics (including uncertainty standard error) results GAM fit. seasonal metric can summary function available R, seasonal maxima (max), minima (min), variance (var), others. function uses repeated resampling GAM model coefficients simulate multiple time series estimate uncertainty summary parameter. inputs anlz_metseason() include seasonal range day year using start (doystr) end (doyend) days metfun nsim arguments specify summary function number simulations, respectively. show estimate maximum chlorophyll season, using relatively low number simulations. Repeating function produce similar slightly different results estimates stochastic. practice, large value nsim used produce accurate results (e.g., nsim = 1e5). anlz_mixmeta() function uses results anlz_metseason() estimate trend seasonal metric selected year range. , evaluate seasonal trend 2006 2017 seasonal estimate model results . show_metseason() function plots seasonal metrics trends time. anlz_metseason() anlz_mixmeta() functions used internally get predictions. arguments functions used show_metseason, mean default metric.  plot seasonal metrics, regression line showing trends time can suppressed setting one yrstr yrend NULL.  Adding argument metfun show_metseason() plot results trends metric average. Note use nsim example. practice, much higher value used (e.g., nsim = 1e5)  seasonal estimates mixed-effects meta-analysis regression can used estimate rate seasonal change across time series. given year seasonal metric, trend can estimated within specific window (.e., yrstr yrend arguments show_metseason()). trend can estimated every year period record estimate rate change time seasonal estimates. anlz_trndseason() function estimates rate change show_trndseason() function plots results. , inputs required anlz_metseason() function required, addition desired window width evaluate year (win) justification window "left", "right", "center" year (justify). ’s important note behavior centering window widths (win argument) choosing even odd values. left right windows, exact number years win used. example, left-centered window 1990 ten years include exactly ten years 1990, 1991, … , 1999. applies right-centered window, e.g., 1990 include 1981, 1982, …, 1990 (years data). However, centered window, picking even number years window width create slightly -centered window impossible center even number years. example, win = 8 justify = 'center', estimate 2000 centered 1997 2004 (three years left, four years right, eight years total). Centering window widths odd number years always create symmetrical window, .e., win = 7 justify = 'center', estimate 2000 centered 1997 2003 (three years left, three years right, seven years total). show_trndseason() function can used plot results directly, one model time.  , adding argument metfun show_trndseason() plot results trends metric average. Note use nsim example. practice, much higher value used (e.g., nsim = 1e5)  results supplied show_trndseason() can extended multiple window widths stacking results single plot. , results window widths 5 15 years shown using show_sumtrndseason() function selected seasonal range using left-justified window. function works average seasonal metrics due long processing times metrics. retrieve results tabular form, use anlz_sumtrndseason().
code: metseason <- anlz_metseason(mod, metfun = max, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, nsim = 100) metseason #> # A tibble: 29 × 7 #>       yr   met     se bt_lwr bt_upr bt_met dispersion #>    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>      <dbl> #>  1  1991 0.264 0.441   0.281   15.1   2.06     0.0434 #>  2  1992 0.825 0.0848  5.11    11.0   7.49     0.0434 #>  3  1993 1.41  0.100  18.3     45.0  28.7      0.0434 #>  4  1994 1.12  0.0963  9.49    22.6  14.6      0.0434 #>  5  1995 1.27  0.0789 14.7     30.0  21.0      0.0434 #>  6  1996 1.31  0.116  13.5     38.3  22.7      0.0434 #>  7  1997 1.41  0.102  18.1     45.3  28.6      0.0434 #>  8  1998 1.96  0.102  63.9    161.  101.       0.0434 #>  9  1999 1.58  0.140  22.6     79.8  42.5      0.0434 #> 10  2000 1.32  0.111  14.1     38.4  23.3      0.0434 #> # ℹ 19 more rows anlz_mixmeta(metseason, yrstr = 2006, yrend = 2017) #> Call:  mixmeta::mixmeta(formula = met ~ yr, S = S, data = totrnd, random = ~1 |  #>     yr, method = "reml") #>  #> Fixed-effects coefficients: #> (Intercept)           yr   #>     72.4739      -0.0355   #>  #> 12 units, 1 outcome, 12 observations, 2 fixed and 1 random-effects parameters #>   logLik       AIC       BIC   #>   8.4127  -10.8255   -9.9177 show_metseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, yrstr = 2006, yrend = 2017, ylab = "Chlorophyll-a (ug/L)") show_metseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, yrstr = NULL, yrend = NULL, ylab = "Chlorophyll-a (ug/L)") show_metseason(mod, metfun = max, nsim = 100, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, yrstr = 2006, yrend = 2017, ylab = "Chlorophyll-a (ug/L)") trndseason <- anlz_trndseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, justify = 'left', win = 5) head(trndseason) #> # A tibble: 6 × 12 #>      yr   met     se bt_lwr bt_upr bt_met dispersion  yrcoef   pval appr_yrcoef #>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>      <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1  1991 0.115 0.535   0.131  16.3    1.46     0.0434  0.0272 0.406        0.358 #> 2  1992 0.684 0.0660  4.02    7.29   5.41     0.0434  0.103  0.0388       1.80  #> 3  1993 0.689 0.0970  3.54    8.49   5.48     0.0434  0.0701 0.264        1.29  #> 4  1994 0.790 0.0862  4.68   10.2    6.91     0.0434  0.0583 0.340        1.25  #> 5  1995 0.728 0.0798  4.18    8.59   5.99     0.0434  0.0490 0.464        1.18  #> 6  1996 1.20  0.0912 11.7    26.8   17.7      0.0434 -0.0613 0.213       -1.51  #> # ℹ 2 more variables: yrcoef_lwr <dbl>, yrcoef_upr <dbl> show_trndseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, justify = 'left', win = 5, ylab = 'Chl. change/yr, average') show_trndseason(mod, metfun = max, nsim = 100, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, justify = 'left', win = 5, ylab = 'Chl. change/yr, maximum') show_sumtrndseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, justify = 'left', win = 5:15)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Marcus Beck. Author, maintainer. Perry de Valpine. Author. Rebecca Murphy. Author. Ian Wren. Author. Ariella Chelsky. Author. Melissa Foley. Author. David Senn. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Beck, M.W., de Valpine, P., Murphy, R., Wren, ., Chelsky, ., Foley, M., Senn, D.B. (2022). “Multi-scale trend analysis water quality using error propagation Generalized Additive Models.” Science Total Environment, 802, 149927. doi:10.1016/j.scitotenv.2021.149927.
code: @Article{,   title = {Multi-scale trend analysis of water quality using error propagation of Generalized Additive Models},   author = {{Beck} and {M.W.} and {de Valpine} and {P.} and {Murphy} and {R.} and {Wren} and {I.} and {Chelsky} and {A.} and {Foley} and {M.} and {Senn} and {D.B.}},   journal = {Science of the Total Environment},   year = {2022},   volume = {802},   pages = {149927},   doi = {10.1016/j.scitotenv.2021.149927}, }

what: Assess Water Quality Trends with Generalized Additive Models
title: Assess Water Quality Trends with Generalized Additive Models
text: R package assess water quality trends long-term monitoring data estuaries using Generalized Additive Models error propagation mixed-effect meta-analysis. Uses concepts mgcv mixmeta packages. Detailed information methods used package described following open access article: Beck, M.W., de Valpine, P., Murphy, R., Wren, ., Chelsky, ., Foley, M., Senn, D.B. 2022. Multi-scale trend analysis water quality using error propagation Generalized Additive Models. Science Total Environment. 802:149927. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2021.149927

title: Assess Water Quality Trends with Generalized Additive Models
text: development version package can installed r-universe. source code available GitHub.
code: # Install wqtrends in R: install.packages('wqtrends', repos = c('https://tbep-tech.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org'))  # load wqtrends library(wqtrends)

title: Assess Water Quality Trends with Generalized Additive Models
text: Please report issues suggestions issues link repository.

code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl') %>%    filter(yr > 2015)  mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') anlz_avgseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180) #> # A tibble: 4 × 7 #>      yr   met     se bt_lwr bt_upr bt_met dispersion #>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1  2016 0.766 0.0839   4.57   9.73   6.67     0.0504 #> 2  2017 0.772 0.0792   4.73   9.68   6.77     0.0504 #> 3  2018 1.03  0.0733   8.75  17.0   12.2      0.0504 #> 4  2019 0.808 0.0719   5.31  10.2    7.34     0.0504

text: mod input model object returned anlz_gam

title: Return summary statistics for GAM fits — anlz_fit

title: Return summary statistics for GAM fits — anlz_fit
text: Results show overall summary model Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), generalized cross-validation score (GCV), R2 values.  Lower values AIC GCV higher values R2 indicate improved model fit.

title: Return summary statistics for GAM fits — anlz_fit
code: library(dplyr)  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl')    mod <-  anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') anlz_fit(mod) #>              AIC        GCV        R2 #> GCV.Cp -3.166885 0.07280572 0.6842621

what: Fit a generalized additive model to a water quality time series — anlz_gam
title: Fit a generalized additive model to a water quality time series — anlz_gam
text: Fit generalized additive model water quality time series

title: Fit a generalized additive model to a water quality time series — anlz_gam
code: anlz_gam(moddat, kts = NULL, ...)

title: Fit a generalized additive model to a water quality time series — anlz_gam
text: moddat input raw data, one station paramater kts optional numeric vector upper limit number knots term s(cont_year), see details ... additional arguments passed methods, .e., trans = 'log10' (default) trans = 'ident' passed anlz_trans

title: Fit a generalized additive model to a water quality time series — anlz_gam
text: gam model object

title: Fit a generalized additive model to a water quality time series — anlz_gam
text: model structure follows: model S: chl ~ s(cont_year, k = large) cont_year vector measured continuous numeric variable annual effect (e.g., January 1st, 2000 2000.0, July 1st, 2000 2000.5, etc.) doy day year numeric value 1 366.  function s models cont_year smoothed, non-linear variable. optimal amount smoothing cont_year determined cross-validation implemented mgcv package upper theoretical upper limit number knots k large enough allow sufficient flexibility smoothing term.  upper limit k chosen 12 times number years input data. insufficient data available fit model specified k, number knots decreased data can modelled, e.g., 11 times number years, 10 times number years, etc.

title: Fit a generalized additive model to a water quality time series — anlz_gam
code: library(dplyr) tomod <- rawdat %>%    filter(station %in% 34) %>%    filter(param %in% 'chl') anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') #>  #> Family: gaussian  #> Link function: identity  #>  #> Formula: #> value ~ s(cont_year, k = 348) #>  #> Estimated degrees of freedom: #> 219  total = 219.93  #>  #> GCV score: 0.07280572

what: Extract period (seasonal) metrics from fitted GAM — anlz_metseason
title: Extract period (seasonal) metrics from fitted GAM — anlz_metseason
text: Extract period (seasonal) metrics fitted GAM

title: Extract period (seasonal) metrics from fitted GAM — anlz_metseason
code: anlz_metseason(mod, metfun = mean, doystr = 1, doyend = 364, nsim = 10000, ...)

title: Extract period (seasonal) metrics from fitted GAM — anlz_metseason
text: mod input model object returned anlz_gam metfun function input metric calculate, e.g., mean, var, max, etc doystr numeric indicating start Julian day extracting averages doyend numeric indicating ending Julian day extracting averages nsim numeric indicating number random draws simulating uncertainty ... additional arguments passed metfun, e.g., na.rm = TRUE)

title: Extract period (seasonal) metrics from fitted GAM — anlz_metseason
text: data frame period metrics

title: Extract period (seasonal) metrics from fitted GAM — anlz_metseason
text: function estimates metric interest given seasonal period year using results fitted GAM (.e., anlz_gam).  estimates based predicted values seasonal period, uncertainty metric based repeated sampling predictions following uncertainty model coefficients.

title: Extract period (seasonal) metrics from fitted GAM — anlz_metseason
code: library(dplyr)  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl') %>%    filter(yr > 2015)  mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') anlz_metseason(mod, mean, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, nsim = 100) #> # A tibble: 4 × 7 #>      yr   met     se bt_lwr bt_upr bt_met dispersion #>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1  2016 0.766 0.0857   4.53   9.81   6.67     0.0504 #> 2  2017 0.772 0.0787   4.75   9.65   6.77     0.0504 #> 3  2018 1.03  0.0812   8.44  17.6   12.2      0.0504 #> 4  2019 0.808 0.0738   5.27  10.2    7.34     0.0504

title: Fit a mixed meta-analysis regression model of trends — anlz_mixmeta
code: library(dplyr)  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl') %>%    filter(yr > 2015)  mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') metseason <- anlz_metseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180) anlz_mixmeta(metseason, yrstr = 2016, yrend = 2019) #> Call:  mixmeta::mixmeta(formula = met ~ yr, S = S, data = totrnd, random = ~1 |  #>     yr, method = "reml") #>  #> Fixed-effects coefficients: #> (Intercept)           yr   #>    -74.0353       0.0371   #>  #> 4 units, 1 outcome, 4 observations, 2 fixed and 1 random-effects parameters #>  logLik      AIC      BIC   #>  1.0749   3.8502  -0.0703   #>

what: Estimate percent change trends from GAM results for selected time periods — anlz_perchg
title: Estimate percent change trends from GAM results for selected time periods — anlz_perchg

title: Estimate percent change trends from GAM results for selected time periods — anlz_perchg
code: library(dplyr)  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl')    mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') anlz_perchg(mod, baseyr = 1990, testyr = 2016) #> # A tibble: 1 × 4 #>   baseval testval perchg  pval #>     <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1    22.8    5.81  -74.5 0.675

text: data.frame summary statistics smoothers GAM

title: Return summary statistics for smoothers of GAMs — anlz_smooth
text: Results show individual effects modelled components model estimated degrees freedom (edf), reference degrees freedom (Ref.df), test statistic (F), significance component (p-value).  significance component part based difference edf Ref.df.

title: Return summary statistics for smoothers of GAMs — anlz_smooth
code: library(dplyr)  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl')    mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') anlz_smooth(mod) #>       smoother      edf   Ref.df        F p.value #> 1 s(cont_year) 218.9304 262.4482 4.788546       0

title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates for multiple window widths — anlz_sumtrndseason
text: mod input model object returned anlz_gam doystr numeric indicating start Julian day extracting averages doyend numeric indicating ending Julian day extracting averages justify chr string indicating justification trend window win numeric vector indicating number years use trend window

title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates for multiple window widths — anlz_sumtrndseason
text: data frame slope estimates p-values year

title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates for multiple window widths — anlz_sumtrndseason
text: function wrapper anlz_trndseason loop across values win, using useave = TRUE quicker calculation average seasonal metrics.  work seasonal metric calculations.

title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates for multiple window widths — anlz_sumtrndseason
code: library(dplyr)  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl') %>%    filter(yr > 2015)  mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') anlz_sumtrndseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, justify = 'center', win = 2:3) #> # A tibble: 8 × 4 #>      yr    yrcoef     pval   win #>   <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl> <int> #> 1  2016   0.00659   0.958      2 #> 2  2017   0.255     0.0289     2 #> 3  2018  -0.220     0.0497     2 #> 4  2019 NaN       NaN          2 #> 5  2016 NaN       NaN          3 #> 6  2017   0.134     0.0605     3 #> 7  2018   0.0166    0.904      3 #> 8  2019 NaN       NaN          3

what: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — anlz_trndseason
title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — anlz_trndseason
text: Estimate seasonal rates change based average estimates

title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — anlz_trndseason
code: anlz_trndseason(   mod,   metfun = mean,   doystr = 1,   doyend = 364,   justify = c("center", "left", "right"),   win = 5,   nsim = 10000,   useave = FALSE,   ... )

title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — anlz_trndseason
text: mod input model object returned anlz_gam metfun function input metric calculate, e.g., mean, var, max, etc doystr numeric indicating start Julian day extracting averages doyend numeric indicating ending Julian day extracting averages justify chr string indicating justification trend window win numeric indicating number years use trend window, see details nsim numeric indicating number random draws simulating uncertainty useave logical indicating anlz_avgseason used seasonal metric calculation ... additional arguments passed metfun, e.g., na.rm = TRUE)

title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — anlz_trndseason
text: data frame slope estimates p-values year

title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — anlz_trndseason
text: Trends based slope fitted linear trend within window, linear trend estimated using meta-analysis regression model (anlz_mixmeta) seasonal metrics (anlz_metseason). Note left right windows, exact number years win used. example, left-centered window 1990 ten years include exactly ten years 1990, 1991, ... , 1999.  applies right-centered window, e.g., 1990 include 1981, 1982, ..., 1990 (years data). However, centered window, picking even number years window width create slightly -centered window impossible center even number years.  example, win = 8 justify = 'center', estimate 2000 centered 1997 2004 (three years left, four years right, eight years total). Centering window widths odd number years always create symmetrical window, .e., win = 7 justify = 'center', estimate 2000 centered 1997 2003 (three years left, three years right, seven years total).

title: Estimate seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — anlz_trndseason
code: library(dplyr)  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl') %>%    filter(yr > 2015)  mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') anlz_trndseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, justify = 'center', win = 4) #> # A tibble: 4 × 12 #>      yr   met     se bt_lwr bt_upr bt_met dispersion   yrcoef    pval #>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>      <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1  2016 0.766 0.0848   4.55   9.77   6.67     0.0504 NaN      NaN     #> 2  2017 0.772 0.0797   4.72   9.70   6.77     0.0504   0.0370   0.565 #> 3  2018 1.03  0.0734   8.75  17.0   12.2      0.0504 NaN      NaN     #> 4  2019 0.808 0.0716   5.32  10.1    7.34     0.0504 NaN      NaN     #> # ℹ 3 more variables: appr_yrcoef <dbl>, yrcoef_lwr <dbl>, yrcoef_upr <dbl>

what: Plot period (seasonal) averages from fitted GAM — show_metseason
title: Plot period (seasonal) averages from fitted GAM — show_metseason
text: Plot period (seasonal) averages fitted GAM

title: Plot period (seasonal) averages from fitted GAM — show_metseason
code: show_metseason(   mod,   metfun = mean,   doystr = 1,   doyend = 364,   yrstr = 2000,   yrend = 2019,   yromit = NULL,   ylab,   nsim = 10000,   useave = FALSE,   base_size = 11,   xlim = NULL,   ylim = NULL,   ... )

title: Plot period (seasonal) averages from fitted GAM — show_metseason
text: mod input model object returned anlz_gam metfun function input metric calculate, e.g., mean, var, max, etc doystr numeric indicating start Julian day extracting averages doyend numeric indicating ending Julian day extracting averages yrstr numeric starting year trend model, see details yrend numeric ending year trend model, see details yromit optional numeric vector years omit plot, see details ylab chr string y-axis label nsim numeric indicating number random draws simulating uncertainty useave logical indicating anlz_avgseason used seasonal metric calculation base_size numeric indicating base font size, passed theme_bw xlim optional numeric vector length two x-axis limits ylim optional numeric vector length two y-axis limits ... additional arguments passed metfun, e.g., na.rm = TRUE)

title: Plot period (seasonal) averages from fitted GAM — show_metseason
text: ggplot object

title: Plot period (seasonal) averages from fitted GAM — show_metseason
text: Setting yrstr yrend NULL suppress plotting trend line meta-analysis regression model. optional omityr vector can used omit years plot trend assessment. may preferred seasonal estimates given year wide confidence intervals likely due limited data, can skew trend assessments. Set useave = T speed calculations metfun = mean.  use anlz_avgseason estimate seasonal summary metrics using non-stochastic equation.

title: Plot period (seasonal) averages from fitted GAM — show_metseason
code: library(dplyr)  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl') %>%    filter(yr > 2015)    mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'ident')  show_metseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, yrstr = 2016, yrend = 2019,       ylab = 'Chlorophyll-a (ug/L)')   # \donttest{ # show seasonal metrics without annual trend show_metseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, yrstr = NULL, yrend = NULL,       ylab = 'Chlorophyll-a (ug/L)')        # omit years from the analysis show_metseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, yrstr = 2015, yrend = 2019,      yromit = 2018, ylab = 'Chlorophyll-a (ug/L)')  # }

code: show_trndseason(   mod,   metfun = mean,   doystr = 1,   doyend = 364,   type = c("log10", "approx"),   justify = c("left", "right", "center"),   win = 5,   ylab,   nsim = 10000,   useave = FALSE,   base_size = 11,   xlim = NULL,   ylim = NULL,   ... )

title: Plot seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — show_trndseason
text: mod input model object returned anlz_gam metfun function input metric calculate, e.g., mean, var, max, etc doystr numeric indicating start Julian day extracting averages doyend numeric indicating ending Julian day extracting averages type chr string indicating log slopes shown (applicable) justify chr string indicating justification trend window win numeric indicating number years use trend window, see details ylab chr string y-axis label nsim numeric indicating number random draws simulating uncertainty useave logical indicating anlz_avgseason used seasonal metric calculation base_size numeric indicating base font size, passed theme_bw xlim optional numeric vector length two x-axis limits ylim optional numeric vector length two y-axis limits ... additional arguments passed metfun, e.g., na.rm = TRUE)

title: Plot seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — show_trndseason
text: ggplot object

title: Plot seasonal rates of change based on average estimates — show_trndseason
code: library(dplyr)  # data to model tomod <- rawdat %>%   filter(station %in% 34) %>%   filter(param %in% 'chl') %>%    filter(yr > 2015)  mod <- anlz_gam(tomod, trans = 'log10') show_trndseason(mod, doystr = 90, doyend = 180, justify = 'left', win = 4,      ylab = 'Slope Chlorophyll-a (ug/L/yr)')

title: wqtrends 1.4.1
text: CRAN release: 2023-08-17 Initial CRAN submission. anlz_gam() try silent, shows cat message knots instead Shortened examples help documentation reduce runtime Update tests show_metseason() anlz_gam() increase coverage Changed README links pass CRAN checks Added CITATION file Added NEWS file

title: wqtrends 1.4.0
text: Added annual argument anlz_pred() return predictions cont_year smoother Vignette clarity appropriate type data use package Fix window centering help file clarification anlz_trndseason() Fix values less zero trans log10 anlz_trans() Returned anlz_avgseason() function package, previously removed generic version function Added anlz_sumtrndseason() show_sumtrndseason() evaluating trends multiple window widths single plot Added useave argument show_meatseason() use anlz_avgseason() estimate, decreases computation time Added base_size argument plot function change base font sizes Fix season day year range hard-coded show_sumtrndseason() Added show_trndseason2() modification show_trndseason() plot summaries seasonal quarters Added documentation update suppressing trend lines show_metseason() Added documentatoin default transformation anlz_gam() Fix anlz_prdmatrix() start date origin using doystr doyend Added dispersion parameter output anlz_avgseason() anlz_metseason() Added yromit argument omit years plot trend show_metseason() Added xlim ylim argument plot functions

title: wqtrends 1.3.0
text: Removed anlz_avgseason(), seasonal metrics estimated anlz_metseason().

title: wqtrends 1.2.0
text: Addition functions calculating generic seasonal metrics

title: wqtrends 1.1.0
text: Update manuscript draft

title: wqtrends 1.0.0
text: First release
